metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh and Others v. Harish Chandra Singh

facts.text: On December 13, 1942, the plaintiff was appointed as Platoon Commander in the Civil Guards.

In 1945 there was a notification regarding the absorption of civil guards in the Police and on November 6, 1945, the plaintiff was selected by the Deputy Inspector General, Police Headquarters, Allahabad, for admission to the 1946 Session of the Police Training College, Moradabad.

On January 8, 1947, the result of the Civil Police Cadets for 1946 Session was announced, and in the extract of the Police Gazette it is stated under the heading where posted, against the name of the plaintiff, Azamgarh. This result sheet was issued by order of the Inspector General of Police, United Provinces.
Plaintiff enlisted on 29-1-47.

In 1950 plaintiff was placed under suspension and was dismissed from service from 2-1-6-1951 while in district Azamgarh. On subsequent consideration he was reinstated and reported for service in January 1952. Reduced to the lowest scale of a S.I. for a period of three years.

Character roll indicates plaintiff was again placed under suspension from 20-8-54 but reinstated on 30-9-54. Soon after placed under suspension from 4-11-54 and proceeded against u/s 7 Police Act, reduced from Rs. 162 p.m. to Rs. 144 p.m. for one year from 8-2-55.
Subsequently awarded a misconduct entry for non-registration of dacoity case while posted in district Basti. Has earned some rewards.

A case Cr. No. 92 u/s 324 IPC was registered at P.S. Mariahun which on receipt of injury report on 6-11-55 was found to fall within s.326 IPC and yet this S.I. did not investigate in accordance with law and failed to comply with orders of Dy.S.P. acting as S.P. given on 19-11-55.

On 21-11-55 a written report of burglary was made over to him by Lalji Singh r/o Jamua who came with Ramdeo and Ganesh but he failed to record that report and register a case in contravention of para 97 of Police Regulations. Case Cr. No. 101 u/s 457/380 IPC registered by him on 5-12-55 although he had been to scene on 27-11-55 and conducted some investigation. Did not prepare case diary on 27-11-55 and deferred proper investigation until 22-12-55.

Report of burglary on night of 17/18-10-55 handed over personally by complainant Raj Bahadur Singh but no action taken, no entry in General Diary. C.I. enquired, directed to register case Cr. No. 100 u/s 457/380 IPC on 2-12-55. Deferred proper investigation until 17-12-55.
Following three charges framed against plaintiff under s.7 Police Act on February 6, 1956.
Superintendent of Police gave report on February 27, 1956 holding plaintiff guilty.
Inspector General ordered fresh enquiry on March 6, 1956.
On April 30, 1956, Superintendent of Police gave report holding plaintiff guilty, mentioned past record, proposed removal from service.
On May 16, 1956, show-cause notice served on plaintiff with copy of SP findings. Stated he could send written representation within 10 days, then appear before DIG.
Plaintiff appeared before Deputy Inspector General of Police, E. Range, answered questions. Stated no complaint with departmental proceedings.
DIG agreed with SP, considered past record, ordered removal from service effective from communication date.
Plaintiff appealed to Inspector General of Police, who rejected appeal, confirmed order, noted leniency.

Plaintiff brought suit against State of UP and Police Officers for declaration that removal order void, illegal; entitled to continue as Station Officer, full pay/emoluments/increments; recovery of Rs. 7,453 from June 27, 1956 to suit date.
Trial Court passed judgment and decree against plaintiff.
Additional District Judge, Varanasi set aside Trial Court judgment, decreed plaintiff's suit.
Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 1271 of 1962 dismissed appeal by State, judgment dated March 2, 1965.
Additional District Judge found plaintiff appointed by Deputy Inspector General of Police per para 406 Police Regulations.

legal_issues.text: Whether the plaintiff was given notice that his past record would be taken into consideration before removal from service.
Whether past record needed to be specifically mentioned in show-cause notice if used for imposing lesser punishment.
Whether plaintiff was appointed by Inspector General or Deputy Inspector General, implicating Art. 311.
Whether plaintiff should have been tried under s.29 Police Act before proceedings under s.7.

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaintiff had notice that his record would be considered because Superintendent of Police mentioned it in report, copy supplied to plaintiff.
If record taken into consideration for imposing lesser punishment and not for increasing quantum/nature, no need to state in show-cause notice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of Mysore v. K. Manche Gowda

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaintiff appointed by Deputy Inspector General, as found by Additional District Judge.

respondent_arguments.text: No opportunity given to offer explanation on past record taken into consideration by DIG.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of Mysore v. K. Manche Gowda (1964) 4 S.C.R. 540

respondent_arguments.text: Breach of Art. 311 because appointed by Inspector General but removed by Deputy Inspector General.
Should have been tried under s.29 Police Act before charged under s.7.

court_reasoning.text: Concluding para of SP report gave indication that record would be considered by DIG; no more notice required.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff had notice via SP report copy.

court_reasoning.text: Past record used for leniency (removal instead of harsher punishment), unlike in Manche Gowda where it aggravated punishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Show-cause notice misled in Manche Gowda; here leniency applied.

court_reasoning.text: Finding of fact by ADJ that appointed by DIG binding; result sheet of 1947 irrelevant to Sub-Inspector appointment.
No necessity to prosecute under s.29 before departmental proceedings under s.7; s.7 disciplinary, s.29 criminal; s.29 does not limit s.7.

holdings.text: Notice of past record consideration was given; used for leniency, not aggravation.
Past record need not be specified in show-cause if for lesser punishment.
No requirement for trial under s.29 before s.7 proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Mysore v. K. Manche Gowda
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished on facts: there past record aggravated punishment without notice; here used for leniency and notice given.

statutes_cited.name: Police Act, 1861
statutes_cited.relevance: S.7 for disciplinary proceedings including removal; s.29 for criminal offences; no bar to s.7 without s.29 prosecution.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Subject to provisions for punishment; no breach as appointing authority was DIG.

statutes_cited.name: Police Regulations
statutes_cited.relevance: Para 97: Register reports; para 406: Appointment authority; para 490: Procedure for findings.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, set aside High Court judgment, upheld the order of removal from service as valid and effective.
outcome.relief_granted: None to plaintiff; state's position upheld.

key_quotes.text: "We, therefore, hold that it is incumbent upon the authority to give the Government servant at the second stage reasonable opportunity to show cause against the proposed punishment and if the proposed punishment is also based on his previous punishment or his previous bad record, this should be included in the second notice so that he may be able to give an explanation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoted from Manche Gowda by High Court; distinguished by SC.

key_quotes.text: "A S.I. acting in this manner is not in my opinion fit to discharge his responsibilities as a police officer. Since, however, no dishonesty has been attributed to him... I think it will meet the ends of justice if he is only removed from police service."
key_quotes.speaker: superintendent_of_police
key_quotes.significance: SP recommends removal considering past record for leniency.

key_quotes.text: "The charges proved against him are very serious and there is no room for me to show him any leniency in the award of punishment."
key_quotes.speaker: deputy_inspector_general
key_quotes.significance: DIG confirms despite past record, notes leniency in removal.
